label.intro:
A useful approach to measuring impact in a community is through Wenger-Trayner’s Evaluation Framework, developed from Donald Kirkpatrick’s four level framework. Five types of value are identified, and we can use these to guide and measure our indicators of success and tell the story of how value is created and developed - and learn from our mistakes if value is not created.

The framework works at several levels, starting at the individual, going up to value felt by stakeholders or even the idea of value itself. The different aspects can be measured by individual interviews and reflections following workshops or specific activities, self-reporting, and impact studies.

During the workshop/event/project:

Immediate value: what was your experience of the workshop/event? Who did you meet?

Potential value: what skills, tools, resources have you gained? How might you use them?

Outside of the workshop/event/project:

Applied value: when have you put into use the skills, tools or resources you gained?

Beyond the workshop/event/project:

Realised value: how has what you gained created wider impact?

Value reframed: has the concept of value itself in this area changed?
